posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Hi eltalstro,
The build is far from optimised, e.g. Improved initiative should be swapped with something like Called Shot or Blind Fight, and it is not hard to add EWF and even EP if you are willing to start out with a higher dexterity. You will most probably not want the discipline skill because it is a dex'er, a ranged attacker and because you invest a lot to simply avoid being hit. One may also debate if not listen is better than spot or if you want them both.
What I find most interesting is the discussion that follows the build. Is SC5 worth it/ is it the best way to achieve 50% concealment? Can you build with Rogue instead of SD? Will 50% concealment also protect against spells etc.

The combination of 50% concealment, ED and a high AC no doubt is very effective against physical attacks, an important reason why dexers become better in high magic environments. Another reason for that is high weapon enhancements that compensate for a lower strength  based damage bonus.
In this particular build, you sacrifice 6 AA levels (3AB and 3 damage) compared to a build with SD 10 and ED alone.
The claim that concealment protects against magical attacks is not documented anywhere (as far as I can see), but it is not unreasonable to assume that it protects against magic that depends on a touch attack.

Now can it be done with Rogue rather than SD? Indeed it can!
And if you want to avoid the xp penalty that comes with the Bard/Rogue combo for elves, you simply build with Wizard. Here is an example:

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'm not sure whether SC5 and HiPs and ED isn't something of an overkill, and that any 2 of the 3 should do the job. I'd keep ED for True Seers and folk with a particularly high Spot skill (or when you dash in hasted to PBS an annoying mage to death by ignoring damage shields, etc) and go for either of the other 2. For this particular build, where you don't want to get involved in melee at all, I'd have thought HiPS should be enough (thus allowing for the 6 extra AA levels as Mick mentions), unless it has a "cool-down" element implemented. Mick's version (above) takes the opposite route, which seems to work fine - and you don't need Dodge and Mobility with it, so effectively you have 2 free feats to use, while the SD option will mean dipping out on one of Called Shot, Blind Fight, or Imp Crit. However, it opens up more options in epic levels. It's all a bit of a trade-off, as are so many things NwN-related.

Cheers

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I have levelled the Bard 8/SD16/AA 16 build to 40 on WoG.

The great thing about it is that one does not have rog SA to worry about.  By this, I mean SA, which needs to be within short range to get SA.

Basically, this is a Sneak build.  You run and gun but use HiPS to "get away" from your opponent.  reposition and rinse, repeat, until the opponent is dead.  Superb defense, the 16 levels of AA are enough to get out of the "poke poke" syndrome that alot of Dex builds have (due to low damage output) - arrow enchantment is +8 here, which is good for a medium magic environment (but will suffer accordingly in a high magic environment).

Anyway, that is basically it.  One does have Bard Song, of course.  That will boost AB a bit.  Not that it is really needed - perhaps for those End Bosses that have impossibly high ACs.

The only thing I have to add to the SC5+ED discussion is that despite the mathematically low chance of being hit, I manage to get hit more than one would expect to be - dunno why.  It's not often enough to be deadly, most of the time, but it is noticeable.  What I do notice is that most (if not all) of the hits are not crits - meaning that one is dealing with mostly normal damage. 

On WoG, the environment is very harsh, but this build performs very well (it is very expensive due to arrow consumption!) - even against opponents that have vanilla True Sight.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
On WoG (and I suspect any environment where dispelling is a real threat) having SCV is ZOMG.  Invis and Displacement gets blown right off (Dispel spam supreme) - and even though one can normally put it back on, that takes time. Monks get a non-dispellable version of it 2/Day that last for a good bit and Assassin gets one as well.

Which can be a problem when surrounded by m0bs that are hell bent on tearing you into little itty bitty pieces...and ED is mega-ZOMG super cheese.  Combined, with a high AC, and it makes for a really awesome build imo.

Oh, btw - I forgot to mention HiPS.  In an environment where vanilla HiPS is allowed, it is totally OP.  One should put it on the Quickbar, with the Attack command right next to it.  Then, just use the F keys that correspond to the Quickslotted commands to toggle HiPS and Attack (meaning if you are in combat, you need to first toggle Attack OFF and then HiPS, then you can attack at your leisure).  You can also use this technique to "break" caster LoS so that their spells do not go off at you - just toggle it like a madman!  One-Two, rinse, repeat.  Especially with ranged, this works wonders!  I just keep the mouse pointer on the target and toggle the F keys.

You'll never get a spell cast at you, m0bs will "forget" you are there and stop attacking/advancing towards you, etc.  It is the ultimate "cheese mode".

Even in an environment where HiPS is on a timer, one can still do this - albeit with less effectiveness.
